revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} <!-- PLEASE DO NOT CHANGE THE SPELLING OF ANY WORD THAT HAS AE OR OE INSTEAD OF E, THE BRISTOL STOOL SCALE ORIGINATED IN BRITAIN AND SHOULD THEREFORE ADOPT THE BRITISH SPELLING - SEE WP:ENGVAR --> {{Infobox diagnostic | name = Bristol stool scale | image = File:BristolStoolChart.png|thumb| | alt = | caption = Bristol stool chart | pronounce = | purpose =classify type of feces(diagnostic triad for irritable bowel syndrome) | test of = | based on = | synonyms = | reference_range = | calculator = | DiseasesDB = <!--{{DiseasesDB2|numeric_id}}--> | ICD10 = <!--{{ICD10|Group|Major|minor|LinkGroup|LinkMajor}} or {{ICD10PCS|code|char1/char2/char3/char4}}--> | ICD9 = | ICDO = | MedlinePlus = <!--article_number--> | eMedicine = <!--article_number--> | MeshID = | OPS301 = <!--{{OPS301|code}}--> | LOINC = <!--{{LOINC|code}}--> }}
The '''Bristol stool scale''' is a diagnostic [[medicine|medical]] tool designed to classify the form of [[human feces|human faeces]] into seven categories. It is used in both clinical and [[scientific method|experimental]] fields.<ref name="Koh-2010">{{cite journal|last1=Koh|first1=H.|last2=Lee|first2=MJ.|last3=Kim|first3=MJ.|last4=Shin|first4=JI.|last5=Chung|first5=KS.|title=Simple diagnostic approach to childhood fecal retention using the Leech score and Bristol stool form scale in medical practice|journal=J Gastroenterol Hepatol|volume=25|issue=2|pages=334–8|date=February 2010|doi=10.1111/j.1440-1746.2009.06015.x|pmid=19817956}}</ref><ref name="Corsetti-2009">{{cite journal|last1=Corsetti|first1=M.|first2=P.|last2=De Nardi|first3=S.|last3=Di Pietro|first4=S.|last4=Passaretti|first5=PA.|last5=Testoni|first6=C.|last6=Staudacher|title=Rectal distensibility and symptoms after stapled and Milligan-Morgan operation for hemorrhoids|journal=J Gastrointest Surg|volume=13|issue=12|pages=2245–51|date=December 2009|doi=10.1007/s11605-009-0983-7|pmid=19672663}}</ref><ref name="Wang-2004">{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=HJ.|first2=XM.|last2=Liang|first3=ZL.|last3=Yu|first4=LY.|last4=Zhou|first5=SR.|last5=Lin|first6=M.|last6=Geraint|title=A Randomised, Controlled Comparison of Low-Dose Polyethylene Glycol 3350 plus Electrolytes with Ispaghula Husk in the Treatment of Adults with Chronic Functional Constipation|journal=Clin Drug Investig|volume=24|issue=10|pages=569–76|year=2004|pmid=17523718|doi=10.2165/00044011-200424100-00002}}</ref> It is sometimes also referred to as the '''Bristol stool chart''' ('''BSC'''),<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Amarenco G|title=Bristol Stool Chart: étude prospective et monocentrique de "l'introspection fécale" chez des sujets volontaires|trans-title=Bristol Stool Chart: Prospective and monocentric study of 'stools introspection' in healthy subjects|language=French|journal=Progrès en Urologie|volume=24|issue=11|pages=708–13|year=2014|pmid=25214452|doi=10.1016/j.purol.2014.06.008}}</ref> '''Bristol stool form scale''', or '''BSF scale'''.<ref>[https://www.gutsense.org/constipation/normal_stools.html Gut Sense] What Exactly Are Normal Stools?, Konstantin Monastyrsky. Accessed July 2015</ref>
It was developed at the [[Bristol Royal Infirmary]] as a clinical assessment tool in 1997, and is widely used as a research tool to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments for various diseases of the bowel, as well as a clinical communication aid;<ref name="Elsevier Health Sciences">{{cite book|last1=Ackley|first1=Betty J.|last2=Ladwig|first2=Gail B.|title=Nursing Diagnosis Handbook, An Evidence-Based Guide to Planning Care, 10: Nursing Diagnosis Handbook|year=2013|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780323085496|page=240}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Bristol scale stool form. A still valid help in medical practice and clinical research G Riegler, I Esposito – ''Techniques in coloproctology'', 2001 – Springer</ref> including being part of the diagnostic triad for [[irritable bowel syndrome]].<ref name=NICE-IBS-2008>{{cite journal|last1=National Collaborating Centre for Nursing and Supportive Care|first1=(UK)|title=Irritable Bowel Syndrome in Adults: Diagnosis and Management of Irritable Bowel Syndrome in Primary Care, NICE Clinical Guidelines, No. 61|date=February 2008|pmid=21656972|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0009973/|accessdate=17 November 2015}}</ref>
== Interpretation of the scale == The seven types of stool are:<ref name="Mínguez Pérez-2009"/>
*Type 1: Separate hard lumps, like nuts (hard to pass) *Type 2: Sausage-shaped, but lumpy *Type 3: Like a sausage but with cracks on its surface *Type 4: Like a sausage or snake, smooth and soft *Type 5: Soft blobs with clear cut edges (easy to pass) *Type 6: Fluffy pieces with ragged edges, a mushy stool *Type 7: Watery, no solid pieces, entirely liquid
Types 1 and 2 indicate [[constipation]], with 4 being the ideal stools as they are easy to [[defecation|defecate]] while not containing excess liquid, 5 tending towards <!-- PLEASE DO NOT CHANGE THE SPELLING OF DIARRHOEA, THE BRISTOL STOOL SCALE ORIGINATED IN BRITAIN AND SHOULD THEREFORE ADOPT THE BRITISH SPELLING - SEE WP:ENGVAR -->[[diarrhea|diarrhoea]], and 6 and 7 indicate diarrhoea.<ref name="LacyPatel2017">{{cite journal| vauthors=Lacy BE, Patel NK| title=Rome Criteria and a Diagnostic Approach to Irritable Bowel Syndrome. | journal=J Clin Med | year= 2017 | volume= 6 | issue= 11 | pages= 99| pmid=29072609 | doi=10.3390/jcm6110099 | pmc=5704116 | type=Review }}</ref>
In the initial study, in the population examined in this scale, the type 1 and 2 stools were more prevalent in females, while the type 5 and 6 stools were more prevalent in males; furthermore, 80% of subjects who reported [[rectal tenesmus]] (urgency to defecate) had type 7. These and other data have allowed the scale to be validated.<ref name="Mínguez Pérez-2009">{{cite journal|last1=Mínguez Pérez|first1=M.|first2=A.|last2=Benages Martínez|title=The Bristol scale - a useful system to assess stool form?|journal=Rev Esp Enferm Dig|volume=101|issue=5|pages=305–11|date=May 2009|pmid=19527075|doi=10.4321/s1130-01082009000500001}}</ref>
The Bristol stool scale is also very sensitive to changes in intestinal transit time caused by medications, such as [[diarrhea|antidiarrhoeal]] [[loperamide]] or [[senna glycoside|senna]], [[anthraquinone]] substance with [[laxative]] effect.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lewis|first1=SJ.|first2=KW.|last2=Heaton|title=Stool form scale as a useful guide to intestinal transit time|journal=Scand J Gastroenterol|volume=32|issue=9|pages=920–4|date=September 1997|doi=10.3109/00365529709011203|pmid=9299672}}</ref>
==History== Developed and proposed for the first time in [[England]] by Dr. Stephen Lewis and Dr. Ken Heaton at the University Department of Medicine, [[Bristol Royal Infirmary]], it was suggested by the authors as a clinical assessment tool in 1997 in the journal ''[[Scandinavian Journal of Gastroenterology]]''<ref name="Lewis-1997">{{cite journal|vauthors=Lewis SJ, Heaton KW|title=Stool form scale as a useful guide to intestinal transit time|journal=Scand. J. Gastroenterol.|volume=32|issue=9|pages=920–4|date=September 1997|doi=10.3109/00365529709011203|pmid=9299672}}</ref> after a previous [[prospective cohort study|prospective study]], conducted in 1992 on a [[sampling (statistics)|sample]] of the population (838 men and 1,059 women), had shown an unexpected [[prevalence]] of [[defecation]] disorders related to the shape and type of stool.<ref name="Heaton-1992">{{cite journal|last1=Heaton|first1=KW.|first2=J.|last2=Radvan|first3=H.|last3=Cripps|first4=RA.|last4=Mountford|first5=FE.|last5=Braddon|first6=AO.|last6=Hughes|title=Defecation frequency and timing, and stool form in the general population: a prospective study|journal=Gut|volume=33|issue=6|pages=818–24|date=June 1992|pmid=1624166|doi=10.1136/gut.33.6.818|pmc=1379343}}</ref> The authors of the former paper concluded that the form of the stool is a useful surrogate measure of [[colon (anatomy)|colon]] transit time. That conclusion has since been challenged as having limited validity for Types 1 and 2;<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Rao SS, Camilleri M, Hasler WL, Maurer AH, Parkman HP, Saad R, Scott MS, Simren M, Soffer E, Szarka L|title=Evaluation of gastrointestinal transit in clinical practice: position paper of the American and European Neurogastroenterology and Motility Societies|journal=Neurogastroenterol. Motil.|volume=23|issue=1|pages=8–23|year=2011|pmid=21138500|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2982.2010.01612.x}}</ref> however, it remains in use as a research tool to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments for various diseases of the bowel, as well as a clinical communication aid.<ref name="Elsevier Health Sciences"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/>
== Versions == The same scale has been validated in [[Spanish language|Spanish]],<ref name="Parés-2009">{{cite journal|last1=Parés|first1=D.|first2=M.|last2=Comas|first3=D.|last3=Dorcaratto|first4=MI.|last4=Araujo|first5=M.|last5=Vial|first6=B.|last6=Bohle|first7=M.|last7=Pera|first8=L.|last8=Grande|title=Adaptation and validation of the Bristol scale stool form translated into the Spanish language among health professionals and patients|journal=Rev Esp Enferm Dig|volume=101|issue=5|pages=312–6|date=May 2009|pmid=19527076|doi=10.4321/s1130-01082009000500002}}</ref><ref name="Maestre-2010">{{cite journal|last1=Maestre|first1=Y.|first2=D.|last2=Parés|first3=M.|last3=Vial|first4=B.|last4=Bohle|first5=M.|last5=Sala|first6=L.|last6=Grande|title=Prevalence of fecal incontinence and its relationship with bowel habit in patients attended in primary care|journal=Med Clin (Barc)|volume=135|issue=2|pages=59–62|date=June 2010|doi=10.1016/j.medcli.2010.01.031|pmid=20416902}}</ref> [[Brazilian Portuguese]],<ref name="Martinez-2012">{{Cite journal| volume = 20| issue = 3| pages = 583–589| last1 = Martinez| first1 = AP| last2 = de Azevedo| first2 = GR.| title = The Bristol Stool Form Scale: its translation to Portuguese, cultural adaptation and validation| journal = Rev Lat Am Enfermagem| date = 2012 |doi =10.1590/S0104-11692012000300021| pmid = 22991122}}</ref> and [[Polish language|Polish]] versions.<ref name="Wojtyniak-2018">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.5114/pg.2017.70610| volume = 13| issue = 1| pages = 35–39| last1 = Wojtyniak| first1 = K.| last2 = Szajewska| first2 = H.| last3 = Dziechciarz| first3 = P.| title = Translation to Polish, cross-cultural adaptation, and validation of the Bristol Stool Form Scale among healthcare professionals and patients |language=en| journal = Prz Gastroenterol| date = 2018| pmid = 29657609| pmc = 5894444}} [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5894444/figure/f0001/?report=objectonly Fig. 1: Polish BSFS] (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0)</ref> A version has also been designed and validated for [[paediatrics]].<ref name="Chumpitazi-2010">{{cite journal|last1=Chumpitazi|first1=BP.|first2=MM.|last2=Lane|first3=DI.|last3=Czyzewski|first4=EM.|last4=Weidler|first5=PR.|last5=Swank|first6=RJ.|last6=Shulman|title=Creation and initial evaluation of a stool form scale for children|journal=J Pediatr|volume=157|issue=4|pages=594–7|date=October 2010|doi=10.1016/j.jpeds.2010.04.040|pmid=20826285|pmc=2937014}}</ref><ref name="Candy-">{{cite journal|last1=Candy|first1=D.|first2=S.|last2=Paul|title=Go with the flow: in childhood constipation|journal=J Fam Health Care|volume=21|issue=5|pages=35, 37–8, 40–1 passim|pmid=22132564|year=2011}}</ref> More recently, in September 2011, a modified version of the scale was validated using a criterion of self-assessment for ages 6–8 years of age.<ref name="Lane-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Lane|first1=MM.|first2=DI.|last2=Czyzewski|first3=BP.|last3=Chumpitazi|first4=RJ.|last4=Shulman|title=Reliability and validity of a modified Bristol Stool Form Scale for children|journal=J Pediatr|volume=159|issue=3|pages=437–441.e1|date=September 2011|doi=10.1016/j.jpeds.2011.03.002|pmid=21489557|pmc=3741451}}</ref>
A version of the scale was developed into a chart suitable for use on US television by Dr. Gary Kahan of [[NewYork–Presbyterian Hospital]].<ref name="Leader">{{cite book|last1=Leader|first1=Lucille|last2=Leader|first2=Serena |last3=Leader|first3=Geoffrey|title=Medical Collaboration for Nutritional Therapists|year=2009|publisher=Denor Press|isbn=9780952605652|page=56|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j7CUQAAACAAJ}}</ref>
== Uses == === Diagnosis of IBS === {{see also|irritable bowel syndrome|Rome process}} Patients with [[irritable bowel syndrome|IBS]] or irritable bowel syndrome typically report that they suffer with abdominal [[cramp]]s and [[constipation]]. In some patients, chronic constipation is interspersed with brief episodes of [[diarrhea|diarrhoea]]; while a minority of patients with IBS have only diarrhoea. The presentation of symptoms is usually months or years and commonly patients consult different doctors, without great success, and doing various specialized investigations. It notices a strong correlation of the reported symptoms with [[stress (biology)|stress]]; indeed diarrhoeal discharges are associated with [[emotion|emotional phenomena]]. IBS blood is present only if the disease is associated with [[hemorrhoid|haemorrhoid]]s.<ref name="Longstreth-2006"/>
Research conducted on irritable bowel syndrome in the 2000s,<ref name="Yilmaz-2005">{{cite journal|last1=Yilmaz|first1=S.|first2=M.|last2=Dursun|first3=M.|last3=Ertem|first4=F.|last4=Canoruc|first5=A.|last5=Turhanoğlu|title=The epidemiological aspects of irritable bowel syndrome in Southeastern Anatolia: a stratified randomised community-based study|journal=Int J Clin Pract|volume=59|issue=3|pages=361–9|date=March 2005|doi=10.1111/j.1742-1241.2004.00377.x|pmid=15857337}}</ref><ref name="Adibi-2007">{{cite journal|last1=Adibi|first1=P.|first2=E.|last2=Behzad|first3=S.|last3=Pirzadeh|first4=M.|last4=Mohseni|title=Bowel habit reference values and abnormalities in young Iranian healthy adults|journal=Dig Dis Sci|volume=52|issue=8|pages=1810–3|date=August 2007|doi=10.1007/s10620-006-9509-2|pmid=17410463}}</ref> [[fecal incontinence|faecal incontinence]]<ref name="Macmillan-2008">{{cite journal|last1=Macmillan|first1=AK.|first2=AE.|last2=Merrie|first3=RJ.|last3=Marshall|first4=BR.|last4=Parry|title=Design and validation of a comprehensive fecal incontinence questionnaire|journal=Dis Colon Rectum|volume=51|issue=10|pages=1502–22|date=October 2008|doi=10.1007/s10350-008-9301-9|pmid=18626716}}</ref><ref name="Chung-2010">{{cite journal|last1=Chung|first1=JM.|first2=SD.|last2=Lee|first3=DI.|last3=Kang|first4=DD.|last4=Kwon|first5=KS.|last5=Kim|first6=SY.|last6=Kim|first7=HG.|last7=Kim|first8=du G.|last8=Moon|first9=KH.|last9=Park|first10=YH.|last10=Park|first11=KS.|last11=Pai|title=An epidemiologic study of voiding and bowel habits in Korean children: a nationwide multicenter study|journal=Urology|volume=76|issue=1|pages=215–9|date=July 2010|doi=10.1016/j.urology.2009.12.022|pmid=20163840|url=http://repository.ajou.ac.kr/handle/201003/2650}}</ref><ref name="Maestre-2010"/><ref name="El-Gazzaz-2009">{{cite journal|last1=El-Gazzaz|first1=G.|first2=M.|last2=Zutshi|first3=L.|last3=Salcedo|first4=J.|last4=Hammel|first5=R.|last5=Rackley|first6=T.|last6=Hull|title=Sacral neuromodulation for the treatment of fecal incontinence and urinary incontinence in female patients: long-term follow-up|journal=Int J Colorectal Dis|volume=24|issue=12|pages=1377–81|date=December 2009|doi=10.1007/s00384-009-0745-8|pmid=19488765}}</ref> and the gastrointestinal complications of [[HIV]]<ref name="Tinmouth-">{{cite journal|last1=Tinmouth|first1=J.|first2=G.|last2=Tomlinson|first3=G.|last3=Kandel|first4=S.|last4=Walmsley|first5=HA.|last5=Steinhart|first6=R.|last6=Glazier|title=Evaluation of Stool frequency and stool form as measures of HIV-related diarrhea|journal=HIV Clin Trials|volume=8|issue=6|pages=421–8|doi=10.1310/hct0806-421|pmid=18042507|year=2007}}</ref> have used the Bristol scale as a diagnostic tool easy to use; even in research which lasted for 77 months.<ref name="Zutshi-2009">{{cite journal|last1=Zutshi|first1=M.|first2=TH.|last2=Tracey|first3=J.|last3=Bast|first4=A.|last4=Halverson|first5=J.|last5=Na|title=Ten-year outcome after anal sphincter repair for fecal incontinence|journal=Dis Colon Rectum|volume=52|issue=6|pages=1089–94|date=June 2009|doi=10.1007/DCR.0b013e3181a0a79c|pmid=19581851}}</ref>
Historically, this scale of assessment of the faeces has been recommended by the [[consensus decision-making|consensus group]] of [[Kaiser Permanente]] Medical Care Program ([[San Diego]], [[California]]) for the collection of data on functional bowel disease (FBD).<ref name="Longstreth-2006">{{cite journal|last1=Longstreth|first1=GF.|first2=WG.|last2=Thompson|first3=WD.|last3=Chey|first4=LA.|last4=Houghton|first5=F.|last5=Mearin|first6=RC.|last6=Spiller|title=Functional bowel disorders|journal=Gastroenterology|volume=130|issue=5|pages=1480–91|date=April 2006|doi=10.1053/j.gastro.2005.11.061|pmid=16678561}}</ref>
More recently, according to the latest revision of the [[Rome process|Rome III Criteria]], six clinical manifestations of IBS can be identified:<ref name="Park-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Park|first1=JM.|first2=MG.|last2=Choi|first3=YK.|last3=Cho|first4=IS.|last4=Lee|first5=JI.|last5=Kim|first6=SW.|last6=Kim|first7=IS.|last7=Chung|title=Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders Diagnosed by Rome III Questionnaire in Korea|journal=J Neurogastroenterol Motil|volume=17|issue=3|pages=279–86|date=July 2011|doi=10.5056/jnm.2011.17.3.279|pmid=21860820|pmc=3155064}}</ref><ref name="Dong-2010">{{cite journal|last1=Dong|first1=YY.|first2=XL.|last2=Zuo|first3=CQ.|last3=Li|first4=YB.|last4=Yu|first5=QJ.|last5=Zhao|first6=YQ.|last6=Li|title=Prevalence of irritable bowel syndrome in Chinese college and university students assessed using Rome III criteria|journal=World J Gastroenterol|volume=16|issue=33|pages=4221–6|date=September 2010|pmid=20806442|doi=10.3748/wjg.v16.i33.4221|pmc=2932929}}</ref><ref name="Sorouri-">{{cite journal|last1=Sorouri|first1=M.|first2=MA.|last2=Pourhoseingholi|first3=M.|last3=Vahedi|first4=A.|last4=Safaee|first5=B.|last5=Moghimi-Dehkordi|first6=A.|last6=Pourhoseingholi|first7=M.|last7=Habibi|first8=MR.|last8=Zali|title=Functional bowel disorders in Iranian population using Rome III criteria|journal=Saudi J Gastroenterol|volume=16|issue=3|pages=154–60|doi=10.4103/1319-3767.65183|pmid=20616409|pmc=3003223|year=2010}}</ref><ref name="Miwa-2008">{{cite journal|last1=Miwa|first1=H.|title=Prevalence of irritable bowel syndrome in Japan: Internet survey using Rome III criteria|journal=Patient Prefer Adherence|volume=2|pages=143–7|year=2008|pmid=19920955|pmc=2770425}}</ref><ref name="Engsbro-2012">{{cite journal|last1=Engsbro|first1=AL.|first2=M.|last2=Simren|first3=P.|last3=Bytzer|title=Short-term stability of subtypes in the irritable bowel syndrome: prospective evaluation using the Rome III classification|journal=Aliment Pharmacol Ther|volume=35|issue=3|pages=350–9|date=February 2012|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2036.2011.04948.x|pmid=22176384}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;clear:both;" !Subtypes prevalent presentation of stool in IBS according to the ''Rome III Criteria''<ref name="urlMedscape Log In">{{cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/562737_4|title=Medscape Log In|author=|date=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |1. IBS with constipation ('''IBS-C''') - lumpy or hard stools * ≥ 25% and loose (soft) or watery stools † <25% of bowel movements. ‡ |- |2. IBS with diarrhea ('''IBS-D''') - loose (soft) or watery stools † ≥ 25% and lumpy or hard stools * <25% of bowel movements. ‡ |- |3. Mixed IBS ('''IBS - M''') - lumpy or hard stools * ≥ 25% and loose (soft) or watery stools † ≥ 25% of bowel movements. ‡ |- |4. Untyped IBS ('''IBS - U''') - insufficient stool abnormalities to be '''IBS-C''', '''D''' or '''M''' ‡ |- |<small>* Bristol stool scale type 1-2 (Separate hard lumps like nuts (difficult defecation) or sausage-shaped);<br /> † Bristol stool scale type 6-7 (fluffy pieces with ragged edges, soft or watery, no solid or completely liquid pieces);<br /> ‡ In the absence of the use of [[antidiarrhoeal]] or [[laxative]].</small> |- |}
These four identified subtypes correlate with the consistency of the stool, which can be determined by the Bristol stool scale.<ref name="Longstreth-2006"/>
[[File:IBS sottotipi.png|thumb|centre|upright=1.8|Graphical representation of four presentations notes of IBS, and the role of percentage of stool consistency of types 1 and 2 ([[constipation]], ordinate) and of types 6 and 7 ([[diarrhea|diarrhoea]], abscissa) according to the scale of Bristol<ref name="urlIBS, Irritable Bowel Syndrome">{{cite web|url=http://www.indiasurgeons.com/lectures/ibs.htm|title=IBS, Irritable Bowel Syndrome|author=|date=|access-date=}}</ref>]]
In 2007, the ''[[Mayo Medical School|Mayo Clinic College of Medicine]]'' in [[Rochester, Minnesota|Rochester]] ([[United States]]), reported a piece of [[epidemiology|epidemiological research]] conducted on a population of 4,196 people living in [[Olmsted County, Minnesota|Olmsted County]] ([[Minnesota]]), in which participants were asked to complete a questionnaire based on the ''Bristol stool scale''.<ref name="Choung-2007">{{cite journal|last1=Choung|first1=RS.|first2=GR.|last2=Locke|first3=AR.|last3=Zinsmeister|first4=CD.|last4=Schleck|first5=NJ.|last5=Talley|title=Epidemiology of slow and fast colonic transit using a scale of stool form in a community|journal=Aliment Pharmacol Ther|volume=26|issue=7|pages=1043–50|date=October 2007|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2036.2007.03456.x|pmid=17877511}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;clear:both;" |+ ''Distribution of risk factors in three groups classified <br /> according to the colonic transit and subgroups classified according to the type of feces'' model century<ref name="Choung-2007"/> <br /><br /> !|| Normal <br /> [[colon (anatomy)|colonic]] transit <br /> (BSS 3-4) <br /> (n=1662)||Slow <br /> colonic transit <br /> (BSS 1-2) <br /> (n=411)||Fast <br /> colonic transit <br /> (BSS 5-7) <br /> (n=197) |- |style="width:350px"|Age ([[mean]] ± [[standard deviation|s.d.]]; years)||<center> 62 ± 12</center>||<center> 63 ± 13</center>||<center> 61 ± 12</center> |- |Male (%)||<center> 50</center>||<center> 38</center>||<center> 43</center> |- |[[Body mass index|BMI]] (mean ± s.d.) ||<center> 29,6 ± 7,5</center>|| <center> 28,2 ± 6,8</center>||<center> 32,5 ± 9,9</center> |- |SSC score (mean ± s.d.) <small>(''Somatic Symptom Checklist'')</small>||<center> 1,6 ± 0,50</center>||<center> 1,7 ± 0,53</center>||<center> 1,8 ± 0,57</center> |- |Smoking (%) ||<center> 8</center>||<center> 7</center>||<center> 12</center> |- |Alcohol (%) ||<center> 45</center>||<center> 48</center>||<center> 41</center> |- |[[Cholecystectomy]] (%) ||<center> 11</center>||<center> 12</center>||<center> 19</center> |- |[[Appendectomy]] (%) ||<center> 28</center>||<center> 31</center>||<center> 35</center> |- |[[Combined oral contraceptive pill|Birth control pill]]s (% women)||<center> 3</center>||<center> 5</center>||<center> 3</center> |- |colspan="4" style="background-color:LIGHTCYAN"|<center> '''[[Marital status]]'''</center> |- |Married (%) ||<center> 80</center>||<center> 77</center>||<center> 76</center> |- |colspan="4" style="background-color:LIGHTCYAN"|<center> '''School level'''</center> |- |Compulsory education (%) ||<center> 5</center>||<center> 5</center>||<center> 7</center> |- |High school/some years (%) ||<center> 53</center>||<center> 52</center>||<center> 58</center> |- |Diploma or university (%) ||<center> 41</center>||<center> 42</center>||<center> 36</center> |- |colspan="4" style="background-color:LIGHTCYAN"|<center> '''Family history'''</center> |- |[[Stomach cancer|Gastric cancer]] (%)||<center> 16</center>||<center> 14</center>||<center> 15</center> |- |[[Colorectal cancer|Bowel cancer]] (%)||<center> 12</center>||<center> 11</center>||<center> 15</center> |- |}
The research results (see table) indicate that about 1 in 5 people have a slow transit (type 1 and 2 stools), while 1 in 12 has an accelerated transit (type 5 and 6 stools). Moreover, the nature of the stool is affected by age, sex, [[body mass index]], whether or not they had [[cholecystectomy]] and possible [[psychosomatic medicine|psychosomatic]] components ([[somatization|somatisation]]); there were no effects from factors such as [[smoking]], [[alcoholism|alcohol]], the level of education, a history of [[appendectomy]] or familiarity with gastrointestinal diseases, civil state, or the use of [[combined oral contraceptive pill|oral contraceptive]]s.
=== Therapeutic evaluation === Several investigations correlate the Bristol stool scale in response to medications or therapies, in fact, in one study was also used to titrate the dose more finely than one drug ([[colestyramine]]) in subjects with [[diarrhea|diarrhoea]] and faecal incontinence.<ref name="Remes-Troche-2008">{{cite journal|last1=Remes-Troche|first1=JM.|first2=R.|last2=Ozturk|first3=C.|last3=Philips|first4=M.|last4=Stessman|first5=SS.|last5=Rao|title=Cholestyramine--a useful adjunct for the treatment of patients with fecal incontinence|journal=Int J Colorectal Dis|volume=23|issue=2|pages=189–94|date=February 2008|doi=10.1007/s00384-007-0391-y|pmid=17938939}}</ref>
In a [[randomized controlled trial|randomised controlled study]],<ref name="comparison">{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=HJ.|first2=XM.|last2=Liang|first3=ZL.|last3=Yu|first4=LY.|last4=Zhou|first5=SR.|last5=Lin|first6=M.|last6=Geraint|title=A Randomised, Controlled Comparison of Low-Dose Polyethylene Glycol 3350 plus Electrolytes with Ispaghula Husk in the Treatment of Adults with Chronic Functional Constipation|journal=Clin Drug Investig|volume=24|issue=10|pages=569–76|year=2004|doi=10.2165/00044011-200424100-00002|pmid=17523718}}</ref> the scale is used to study the response to two laxatives: [[Macrogol]] ([[polyethylene glycol]]) and [[psyllium]] (''[[Plantago psyllium]]'' and other [[species]] of the same [[Plantago|genus]]) of 126 male and female patients for a period of 2 weeks of treatment; failing to show the most rapid response and increased efficiency of the former over the latter. In the study, they were measured as primary ''[[outcome (probability)|outcome]]s'': the number weekly bowel movements, stool consistency according to the types of the ''Bristol stool scale'', time to defecation, the overall effectiveness, the difficulty in defecating and stool consistency.<ref name="comparison"/>
From 2010, several clinical studies have used the scale as a diagnostic tool validated for recognition and evaluation of response to various treatments, pharmacological and no, different, such as: [[probiotic]]s,<ref name="Sakai-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Sakai|first1=T.|first2=H.|last2=Makino|first3=E.|last3=Ishikawa|first4=K.|last4=Oishi|first5=A.|last5=Kushiro|title=Fermented milk containing Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota reduces incidence of hard or lumpy stools in healthy population|journal=Int J Food Sci Nutr|volume=62|issue=4|pages=423–30|date=June 2011|doi=10.3109/09637486.2010.542408|pmid=21322768}}</ref><ref name="Riezzo-2012">{{cite journal|last1=Riezzo|first1=G.|first2=A.|last2=Orlando|first3=B.|last3=D'Attoma|first4=V.|last4=Guerra|first5=F.|last5=Valerio|first6=P.|last6=Lavermicocca|first7=S.|last7=De Candia|title=Randomised clinical trial: efficacy of Lactobacillus paracasei-enriched artichokes in the treatment of patients with functional constipation - a double-blind, controlled, crossover study|journal=Aliment Pharmacol Ther|volume=35|issue=4|pages=441–50|date=February 2012|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2036.2011.04970.x|pmid=22225544}}</ref> [[moxibustion|moxicombustion]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Park|first1=JE.|first2=JU.|last2=Sul|first3=K.|last3=Kang|first4=BC.|last4=Shin|first5=KE.|last5=Hong|first6=SM.|last6=Choi|title=The effectiveness of moxibustion for the treatment of functional constipation: a randomized, sham-controlled, patient blinded, pilot clinical trial|journal=BMC Complement Altern Med|volume=11|issue=|pages=124|year=2011|doi=10.1186/1472-6882-11-124|pmid=22132755|pmc=3248868}}</ref> laxatives in the elderly,<ref name="Fosnes-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Fosnes|first1=GS.|first2=S.|last2=Lydersen|first3=PG.|last3=Farup|title=Effectiveness of laxatives in elderly--a cross sectional study in nursing homes|journal=BMC Geriatr|volume=11|issue=|page=76|year=2011|doi=10.1186/1471-2318-11-76|pmid=22093137|pmc=3226585}}</ref> preparing [[Ayurveda|Ayurvedic]] poly-phytotherapy filed TLPL/AY,<ref name="Munshi-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Munshi|first1=R.|first2=S.|last2=Bhalerao|first3=P.|last3=Rathi|first4=VV.|last4=Kuber|first5=SU.|last5=Nipanikar|first6=KP.|last6=Kadbhane|title=An open-label, prospective clinical study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of TLPL/AY/01/2008 in the management of functional constipation|journal=J Ayurveda Integr Med|volume=2|issue=3|pages=144–52|date=July 2011|doi=10.4103/0975-9476.85554|pmid=22022157|pmc=3193686}}</ref> psyllium,<ref name="Pucciani-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Pucciani|first1=F.|first2=M.|last2=Raggioli|first3=MN.|last3=Ringressi|title=Usefulness of psyllium in rehabilitation of obstructed defecation|journal=Tech Coloproctol|volume=15|issue=4|pages=377–83|date=December 2011|doi=10.1007/s10151-011-0722-4|pmid=21779973|hdl=2158/596461}}</ref> [[mesalazine]],<ref name="Bafutto-">{{cite journal|last1=Bafutto|first1=M.|first2=JR.|last2=Almeida|first3=NV.|last3=Leite|first4=EC.|last4=Oliveira|first5=S.|last5=Gabriel-Neto|first6=J.|last6=Rezende-Filho|title=Treatment of postinfectious irritable bowel syndrome and noninfective irritable bowel syndrome with mesalazine|journal=Arq Gastroenterol|volume=48|issue=1|pages=36–40|doi=10.1590/s0004-28032011000100008|pmid=21537540|year=2011}}</ref> [[methylnaltrexone]],<ref name="Michna-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Michna|first1=E.|first2=ER.|last2=Blonsky|first3=S.|last3=Schulman|first4=E.|last4=Tzanis|first5=A.|last5=Manley|first6=H.|last6=Zhang|first7=S.|last7=Iyer|first8=B.|last8=Randazzo|title=Subcutaneous methylnaltrexone for treatment of opioid-induced constipation in patients with chronic, nonmalignant pain: a randomized controlled study.|journal=J Pain|volume=12|issue=5|pages=554–62|date=May 2011|doi=10.1016/j.jpain.2010.11.008|pmid=21429809}}</ref> and [[oxycodone]]/[[naloxone]].<ref name="Clemens-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Clemens|first1=KE.|first2=I.|last2=Quednau|first3=E.|last3=Klaschik|title=Bowel function during pain therapy with oxycodone/naloxone prolonged-release tablets in patients with advanced cancer|journal=Int J Clin Pract|volume=65|issue=4|pages=472–8|date=April 2011|doi=10.1111/j.1742-1241.2011.02634.x|pmid=21401835}}</ref> Or to assess the response to physical activity in athletes.<ref name="Strid-2011">{{cite journal|last1=Strid|first1=H.|first2=M.|last2=Simrén|first3=S.|last3=Störsrud|first4=PO.|last4=Stotzer|first5=R.|last5=Sadik|title=Effect of heavy exercise on gastrointestinal transit in endurance athletes|journal=Scand J Gastroenterol|volume=46|issue=6|pages=673–7|date=June 2011|doi=10.3109/00365521.2011.558110|pmid=21366388}}</ref> ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Large intestine#Structure|Colon]] *[[Constipation]] *[[Diarrhea|Diarrhoea]] *[[Fecal impaction]] *[[Human feces|Human faeces]] *[[Intestine]] {{div col end}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox university | name = City, University of London | image_name = City_University_London_crest.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Old [[Coat of arms|Arms]] of City, University of London | motto = To Serve Mankind | type = [[Public university|Public Research University]] | established = 1852: [[Inns of Court School of Law]]
1894: Northampton Institute
1966: Gained [[Universities in the United Kingdom|University Status]] by [[Royal Charter]]
2016: Constituent College of [[University of London]] |endowment = [[Pound sterling|£]]5.2 million {{small|(as of 31 July 2017)}}{{cite web | url = https://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0004/386869/City-University-Financial-Statements-2016-17.pdf| title = Financial Statements for the Year to 31 July 2017 | accessdate = 11 January 2017| format = PDF | publisher = City, University of London}} |budget = [[Pounds sterling|£]]227.0 million {{small|(2016–17)}} | rector = [[Lord Mayor of the City of London]] [[ex officio]] | president = Sir [[Paul Curran (geographer)|Paul Curran]] | city = [[London]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | campus = Urban | colours = Red and White {{scarf|{{cells|5|#e41f13}}{{cells|5|#FFF}}{{cells|5|#e41f13}}}} | coor = {{Coord|51.52776|N|0.10226|W|type:edu|display=inline,title}} | students = {{HESA student population|INSTID=0115}} ({{HESA year}}){{HESA citation}} | undergrad = {{HESA undergraduate population|INSTID=0115}} ({{HESA year}}) | postgrad = {{HESA postgraduate population|INSTID=0115}} ({{HESA year}}) | affiliations = [[University of London]]
[[Association of MBAs]]
[[European Quality Improvement System|EQUIS]]
[[Universities UK]] | website = {{URL|https://www.city.ac.uk/}} | logo = [[File:City,_University_of_London_Logo,_Sep_2016.jpg|center|250px]] }} '''City, University of London''' is a [[public university|public]] [[research university]] in [[London]], United Kingdom. Since 2016 it has been a constituent college of [[University of London|The University of London]]. It was founded in 1894 as the '''Northampton Institute''' and became a university when '''The City University''' was created by [[royal charter]] in 1966.{{cite web |url=http://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/74867/CharterandStatute.pdf|title=Royal Charter |format=PDF |accessdate=21 January 2013}} The [[Inns of Court School of Law]], which merged with City in 2001, was established in 1852, making it the former City University's oldest constituent part.{{cite web|url =http://www.city.ac.uk/about/city-information/city-review-2011/a-history-of-city-university-london|title =A History of City University London|access-date =1 October 2012|publisher=City University London}} On 1 September 2016, City joined the federal University of London, becoming part of the 18 Colleges and ten research institutes that make up the University.{{cite web| last =Grove| first =Jack| title =City University London to join University of London| website =Times Higher Education| date =16 July 2015| url =https://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/city-university-london-join-university-london| accessdate = 16 July 2015 }} The university has strong links with the [[City of London]], and the [[Lord Mayor of London]] serves as the University's Rector.{{cite web|url=https://www.findamasters.com/masters-degrees/browsebydept.aspx?IID=393|title=City, University of London|website=www.FindAMasters.com|access-date=20 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.city.ac.uk/about/facts-and-achievements/the-city-of-london-and-the-university|title=The City of London and City, University of London|website=City, University of London|access-date=20 November 2017}} City, University of London, has its main campus in [[central London]] in the [[London Borough of Islington|Islington borough]], with additional campuses in Islington and across the City of London, the [[West End of London|West End]] and [[East End]] of London. It is organised into seven schools, within which there are around 40 academic departments and centres, including: the [[Department of Journalism, City University|Department of Journalism]], the [[Cass Business School]], and [[City Law School]] which incorporates the [[Inns of Court School of Law]].{{cite web|url =http://www.city.ac.uk/schools-and-departments|title =Schools and Academic Departments|accessdate =11 December 2011|publisher=City University London}} The annual income of the institution for 2016–17 was £227.0 million of which £11.6 million was from research grants and contracts, with an expenditure of £221.4 million. Cass Business School is ranked 5th in the UK and top 40 in the world in the [[Financial Times]]' 2017 Global MBA Rankings.{{cite web|url=http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/global-mba-ranking-2017|title=Business school rankings from the Financial Times - FT.com|publisher=|access-date=10 February 2017}} City, University of London, is a member of the [[Association of MBAs]], [[European Quality Improvement System|EQUIS]] and [[Universities UK]]. {{TOC limit|limit=3}} ==History== ===Origins=== [[File:Northampton squ.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Northampton Square in front of the main university building]] City University traces its origin to the Northampton Institute, established in 1852 and named after the [[William Compton, 4th Marquess of Northampton|Marquess of Northampton]] who donated the land on which the institute was built, between [[Northampton Square]] and St John Street in [[Islington]]. The institute was established to provide for the education and welfare of the local population. It was constituted under the City of London Parochial Charities Act (1883), with the objective of "the promotion of the industrial skill, general knowledge, health and well-being of young men and women belonging to the poorer classes".{{cite web|url= http://www.city.ac.uk/aboutcity/history.html|title= Our history – City University London|accessdate= 2008-01-30|publisher= City University, London|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080111154506/http://www.city.ac.uk/aboutcity/history.html|archivedate= 11 January 2008|df= dmy-all}} Northampton Polytechnic Institute was an [[institute of technology]] in [[Clerkenwell]], London, founded in 1894. Alumni include [[Colin Cherry]], [[Stuart Davies (engineer)|Stuart Davies]] and [[Anthony Hunt]].{{cite web|url=http://www.senatehouselibrary.ac.uk/our-collections/historic-collections/archives-manuscripts/university-of-london-student-records-1836-1931/ |title=University of London Students 1836-1933 |publisher=Senate House Library |date=1930-06-30 |accessdate=2013-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914105055/http://www.shl.lon.ac.uk/specialcollections/archives/studentrecords.shtml |archivedate=14 September 2010 |df=dmy }} [[Arthur George Cocksedge]], a British [[gymnast]] who competed in the [[1920 Summer Olympics]], was a member of the Northampton Polytechnic Institute's Gymnastics Club and was Champion of the United Kingdom in 1920. In 1937 [[Maurice Dennis]] of the (Northampton Polytechnic ABC) was the 1937 [[ABA Middleweight Champion]]. [[Frederick Handley Page]] was a lecturer in [[aeronautics]] at the institute. The [[Handley Page Type A]], the first powered aircraft designed and built by him, ended up as an instructional airframe at the school. The novelist [[Eric Ambler]] studied engineering at the institute. The six original departments at the institute were Applied Physics and Electrical Engineering; Artistic Crafts; Domestic Economy and Women's Trades; Electro-Chemistry; [[Horology]] (the science of time and art of clock-making); and Mechanical Engineering and Metal Trades. ===20th century=== In 1903–04 a separate technical [[optics]] department was established. In 1909 the first students qualified for [[University of London]] BSc degrees in engineering as internal students. Since 1909 the institute had been involved in [[aeronautics]] education, and in 2009 the School of Engineering and Mathematical Sciences celebrated the centenary of aeronautics at City.{{cite web|url= http://www.city.ac.uk/sems/dps/events/programme.pdf|title= 100 years of education in aeronautics|accessdate= 2009-06-15|publisher= Royal Aeronautical Society}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 1908 the Institute was used for the [[1908 Olympic Games|Olympic Games]]. [[Boxing at the 1908 Summer Olympics|Boxing]] took place at the Institute.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222443/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1908/1908.pdf 1908 Summer Olympics official report.] p 33. The institute was designated a "[[College of Advanced Technology (United Kingdom)|College of Advanced Technology]]" in 1957. In 1961 the institute's involvement in [[information science]] began with the introduction of a course on "Collecting and Communicating Scientific Knowledge". In 1966 City received its [[royal charter]], becoming "The City University" to reflect the institution's close links with the City of London.{{cite web|url= http://www.city.ac.uk/aboutcity/dps/Recent-History-Of-City-University-London-APO-Williams.pdf|title= Progressing through change: The Recent History of City University London, 1978–2008|accessdate= 2009-07-17|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5rYWTZ2dk?url=http://www.city.ac.uk/aboutcity/dps/Recent-History-Of-City-University-London-APO-Williams.pdf|archivedate= 28 July 2010|df= dmy-all}} In 1971 the [[Apollo 15]] astronauts visited City and presented the Vice-Chancellor, Tait, with a piece of [[heat shield]] from the Apollo 15 [[rocket]].{{cite web|url= http://www.city.ac.uk/sems/apollo-15-astronauts.html|title= Video of Apollo 15 astronauts visiting City|accessdate= 2009-06-15|publisher= City University London|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090911091520/http://www.city.ac.uk/sems/apollo-15-astronauts.html|archivedate= 11 September 2009|df= dmy-all}} In October 1995 it was announced that City University would merge with both the [[St Bartholomew School of Nursing & Midwifery]] and the Charterhouse College of Radiography, doubling the number of students in City's Institute of Health Sciences to around 2,500.{{cite news|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=95369§ioncode=26|title=Institute nurses health|access-date=31 December 2011|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=6 October 1995}} ===21st century=== The University formed a strategic alliance with [[Queen Mary, University of London]], in April 2001.{{cite news|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=158856§ioncode=26|title=Queen Mary, City kick off alliance|accessdate=31 December 2011|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=12 April 2001}} In May 2001, a fire in the college building gutted the fourth floor offices and roof.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/may/22/highereducation.news|title=Fire destroys part of City University building|accessdate=29 December 2011 |publisher=The Guardian|date=22 May 2001|location=London|first=Joe|last=Plomin}} In August 2001 City and the [[Inns of Court School of Law]] agreed to merge.{{cite news|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=164514§ioncode=26|title=Law school to merge with City|accessdate=29 December 2011|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=24 August 2001}} Following a donation from [[Sir John Cass's Foundation]], a multimillion-pound building was built at 106 Bunhill Row for the Cass Business School.{{cite news|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=159680§ioncode=26|title=City Business School seeks global profile|accessdate=29 December 2011|publisher=Times Higher Education|date=11 May 2001}} [[File:CollegeBuilding.jpg|thumb|right|220px|The Grade II listed College Building]] A new £23 million building to house the School of Social Sciences and the Department of Language and Communication Science was opened in 2004. The reconstruction and redevelopment of the university's [[Grade II listed]] college building (following the fire in 2001) was completed in July 2006. In 2007 the School of Arts received a £10m building refurbishment. A new students' union venue opened in October 2008 called "TEN squared", which provides a hub for students to socialise in during the day and hosts a wide range of evening entertainment including club nights, society events and quiz nights. In January 2010, premises were shared with the [[University of East Anglia]] (UEA) London, following City's partnership with [[INTO University Partnerships]]. Since then City has resumed its own International Foundation Programme to prepare students for their pre-university year. In April 2011, it was announced that the current halls of residence and Saddler's Sports Centre will be closed and demolished for rebuilding in June 2011. The new student halls and sports facility, now known as CitySport, opened in 2015. In September 2016 City University, London became a member institution of the federal [[University of London]] and changed its name to City, University of London. ==Campus== {{location map|Central London|caption=A map showing the location of the main campus of City, University of London, in central London|lat=51.527636|long=-0.102481}} City has sites throughout London,{{cite web|url = http://www.city.ac.uk/maps/areamaps/index.html|title = University location maps|accessdate = 2009-06-15|publisher = City University London|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090429012107/http://www.city.ac.uk/maps/areamaps/index.html|archivedate = 29 April 2009|df = dmy-all}} with the main campus located at [[Northampton Square]] in the [[Finsbury]] area of [[London Borough of Islington|Islington]]. The Rhind Building which houses the School of Arts and Social Sciences is directly west of Northampton Square. A few buildings of the main campus are located in nearby [[Goswell Road]] in [[Clerkenwell]]. Other academic sites are: * [[City Law School]] (incorporating Inns of Court School of Law) in [[Holborn]], [[London Borough of Camden|Camden]] * [[Cass Business School|Sir John Cass Business School]] in [[St Luke's, London|St Luke's]], Islington, and at [[200 Aldersgate]] in [[Smithfield, London|Smithfield]], City of London * INTO City in [[Spitalfields]], [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets|Tower Hamlets]] ==Organisation and administration== [[File:City,_University_of_London_(University_Building,_Northampton_Sq).jpg|thumb|right|220px|The main entrance of City, University of London, in Northampton Square. The entrance was substantially remodelled in 2017 and opened by the Rector, [[The Princess Royal]]]] The [[Rector (academia)|Rector]] of City, University of London, is the [[Lord Mayor of the City of London]] [[ex officio]]. The day-to-day running of the university is the responsibility of the [[Vice-Chancellor|President]]. The current President is [[Paul Curran (geographer)|Professor Sir Paul Curran]]. ===Schools=== City, University of London is organised into five schools: * [[City Law School]], incorporating [[Inns of Court School of Law]] * [[School of Health Sciences, City University London|School of Health Sciences]], incorporating [[St Bartholomew School of Nursing & Midwifery]] * School of Arts and Social Science, including the [[City University Journalism Department|Department of Journalism]] * School of Mathematics, Computer Science and Engineering * [[Cass Business School|Sir John Cass Business School]] ===Finances=== In the financial year ended 31 July 2011, City had a total income (including share of joint ventures) of £178.6 million (2008/09 – £174.4 million) and total expenditure of £183.62 million (2008/09 – £178.82 million).{{cite web|url=http://www.city.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/110779/Finance_Statements_2011_Web.pdf|title=Financial Statements for the year ended 31 July 2011|accessdate=24 February 2012|publisher=City University London}} Key sources of income included £39.58 million from Funding Council grants (2008/09 – £39.52 million), £116.91 million from tuition fees and education contracts (2008/09 – £104.39 million), £7.86 million from research grants and contracts (2008/09 – £9.29 million), £1.04 from endowment and investment income (2008/09 – £1.83 million) and £15.05 million from other income (2008/09 – £19.37 million). During the 2010/11 financial year, City had a capital expenditure of £9.77 million (2008/09 – £16.13 million). At year end, City had reserves and endowments of £112.89 million (2009/10 – £110.05 million) and total net assets of £147.64 million (2008/09 – £147.27 million). ==Academic profile== ===Courses and rankings=== {{Infobox UK university rankings | ARWU_W = 901–1000 | QS_W = 351 | QS_N = 41 | THE_W = 351–400 | THE_N = 48 | LINE_1 = 0 | Complete = 66 | The_Guardian = 95 | Times/Sunday_Times = 68 | LINE_2 = 0 | TEF = Silver }} City, University of London, offers Bachelor's, Master's, and [[doctorate|Doctoral]] [[academic degree|degrees]] as well as certificates and diplomas at both undergraduate and postgraduate level. More than two thirds of City's programmes are recognised by the appropriate [[professional bodies]] such as the [[British Computer Society|BCS]], [[British Psychological Society|BPS]], [[Chartered Institute of Library and Information Professionals|CILIP]], [[Institution of Civil Engineers|ICE]], [[Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors|RICS]], [[Health Professions Council|HPC]] etc. in recognition of the high standards of relevance to the professions. The University also has an online careers network where over 2,000 former students offer practical help to current students.{{cite web |url = http://www.city.ac.uk/alumni/careers/index.html |title = City's Online Careers Network |accessdate = 2009-06-11 |publisher = City University London |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090422231507/http://www.city.ac.uk/alumni/careers/index.html |archivedate = 22 April 2009 |df = dmy-all }} The [[City Law School]] offers courses for undergraduates, postgraduates, master graduates and professional courses leading to qualification as a solicitor or barrister, as well as continuing professional development. Its Legal Practice Course has the highest quality rating from the [[Solicitors Regulation Authority]].{{cite web |url = http://www.sra.org.uk/documents/students/lpc/exec3innsofcourt.pdf |title = Solicitors Regulation Authority Executive Summary |accessdate = 2009-06-11 |date = 2007-03-20 |publisher = Solicitors Regulation Authority |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101207151511/http://www.sra.org.uk/documents/students/lpc/exec3innsofcourt.pdf |archivedate = 7 December 2010 |df = dmy-all }} The [[School of Community and Health Sciences#Department of Radiography|Department of Radiography]] (part of the [[School of Community and Health Sciences]]) offers two radiography degrees, the [[School of Community and Health Sciences#Diagnostic Radiography|BSc (Hons) Radiography (Diagnostic Imaging)]] and BSc (Hons) Radiography (Radiotherapy and Oncology), both of which are recognised by the [[Health Professions Council]] (HPC). ===Partnerships and collaborations=== ====CETL==== [[Queen Mary, University of London]], and City, University of London, were jointly awarded Centre for Excellence in Teaching and Learning (CETL) status by the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]] (HEFCE) in recognition of their work in skills training for 3,000 students across six healthcare professions.{{cite web|url = http://www.cetl.org.uk/cetl_background.php|title = CETL – Centre for Excellence in Teaching and Learning|accessdate = 2009-02-25|publisher=Queen Mary University of London}} ====City of London==== City, University of London, has links with businesses in the [[City of London]].{{cite web |url = http://www.qaa.ac.uk/reviews/reports/subjectlevel/q96_94_textonly.htm |title = Links with businesses |accessdate = 2007-12-21 |date = 2005-05-24 |publisher = QAA |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090428031933/http://www.qaa.ac.uk/reviews/reports/subjectlevel/q96_94_textonly.htm |archivedate = 28 April 2009 |df = dmy-all }} City has also joined forces with other universities such as [[Queen Mary, University of London|Queen Mary]] and the [[Institute of Education]] (both part of the [[University of London]]) with which it jointly delivers several leading degree programmes. ====LCACE==== [[LCACE|London Centre for Arts and Cultural Exchange]] is a consortium of nine universities. It was established in 2004 to foster collaboration and to promote and support the exchange of knowledge between the consortium's partners and London's arts and cultural sectors. The nine institutions involved are: [[University of the Arts London]]; [[Birkbeck, University of London]]; City, University of London; [[The Courtauld Institute of Art]]; [[Goldsmiths, University of London]]; [[Guildhall School of Music & Drama]]; [[King's College London]]; [[Queen Mary, University of London]], and [[Royal Holloway, University of London]]. ====Simfonec==== Simfonec is a collaborative Science Enterprise Centre (SEC) for the exploitation and transfer of knowledge, ideas and resources among three key sectors – academic, financial and Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). Simfonec encourages the development of an entrepreneurial outlook amongst researchers in science and technology and orchestrates the delivery of science ideas to the commercial marketplace. It is a partnership between four of London universities ([[Royal Veterinary College]], [[King's College London]], [[Queen Mary, University of London]], and City, University of London). It was launched in March 2003 by the [[Department of Trade and Industry (United Kingdom)|Department of Trade and Industry]]. ====Willis Towers Watson Research Network==== In September 2006, City joined the Willis Towers Watson Research Network (WTWRN), a major, long-term partnership between leading international scientific institutions (including the universities of [[University of Bristol|Bristol]], Cambridge, [[Durham University|Durham]] and [[Imperial College London]]) and the global insurance broker [[Willis Towers Watson]]. The purpose of the network is to evaluate the frequency, severity and impact of catastrophes such as hurricanes, earthquakes, floods and terrorism. ====WC2 University Network==== City is a founding member of the WC2 University Network, a network of universities developed with the goal of bringing together leading universities located in the heart of major world cities in order to address cultural, environmental and political issues of common interest to world cities and their universities.{{cite web|url=http://www.city.ac.uk/international/international-partnerships/wc2-university-network|title=WC2 University Network|work=City University London|accessdate=16 July 2015}} In addition to City, University of London, the founding members of WC2 members are: [[City University of New York]], [[Technische Universität Berlin]], [[Universidade de São Paulo]], [[Hong Kong Polytechnic University]], [[Universidad Autonoma Metropolitana]], [[Saint Petersburg State Polytechnical University]], [[Politecnico di Milano]], [[University of Delhi]], [[Northeastern University]] Boston and [[Tongji University]]. ====Erasmus Mundus MULTI==== City was selected as the sole British university to take part in the selective Erasmus Mundus MULTI programme, funded by the [[European Commission]] to promote scientific exchange between Europe and the industrialised countries of South-East Asia. It is the first Erasmus program to involve universities outside of Europe. In addition to City, the partner universities are: [[Aix-Marseille University]] (France), [[Univerzita Karlova v Praze]] (Czech Republic), [[Freie Universität Berlin]] (Germany), [[Universität des Saarlandes]] (Germany), [[Università di Pisa]] (Italy), [[Universidad de Sevilla]] (Spain), [[The Hong Kong Polytechnic University]] (Hong Kong, SAR China), [[Universiti Brunei Darussalam]] (Brunei), [[University of Macau]] (Macau, SAR China), [[Nanyang Technological University]] (Singapore), and [[National Taiwan University]] (Taiwan). ====UCL Partners==== City has joined the executive group of [[UCL Partners]], one of five accredited academic health science groups in the UK. City was invited to join the partnership in recognition of its expertise in nursing, allied health, health services research and evaluation and health management.{{cite web |url=http://www.city.ac.uk/news/2011/august/city-university-london-joins-leading-health-research-partnership |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111104055637/http://www.city.ac.uk/news/2011/august/city-university-london-joins-leading-health-research-partnership |archivedate=4 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ===Spin-out companies=== ====City Technology plc==== City is the birthplace of City Technology plc, which is the world's leading manufacturer of fuel-cell gas sensors used in worker safety, automotive, medical and emissions monitoring applications. City Technology plc was previously listed on the [[London Stock Exchange]] but was acquired by [[Honeywell]] in March 2006. ==Student life== ===Students' Union=== The City Students' Union is run primarily by students through three elected Sabbatical Officers, an Executive Committee and a Union Council, with oversight by a Trustee Board. The Students Union provides support, representation, facilities, services, entertainment and activities for its members. It is run for students by students.{{cite web|url=https://www.citystudents.co.uk/about-us/|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321083722/http://www.city.ac.uk/studentcentre/studentsunion/about_the_su.html|archivedate=21 March 2011|deadurl=yes|access-date=|df=dmy-all}} ===Student media=== City currently has two student media outlets. Both student are student run including Carrot Radio, which currently records weekday podcasts. The second is the student led online magazine, The Howl. They recently released their first print magazine in December 2017. ===Other=== For a number of years, City students have taken part in the annual [[Lord Mayor's Show]], representing the university in one of the country's largest and liveliest parades. ==People & Planet University League== City ranked 7th out of the 168 universities surveyed in the 2016 [[People & Planet]] league table of the most sustainable UK universities. It was the highest ranking University of London institution, and one of only two in the top twenty ([[London School of Economics|LSE]] being 14th).{{cite web|title=University League 2016|url=https://peopleandplanet.org/university-league-2016-tables|publisher=[[People & Planet]]|accessdate=30 July 2017}} The league table's ''Fossil Free Scorecard'' report, drawn from [[Freedom of information in the United Kingdom|Freedom of Information]] requests, found that £800,000 (6.4%) of City's £12.5m endowment was invested in [[fossil fuels]], and that the institution had not made a public commitment to [[fossil fuel divestment]]. It also noted nearly £1m of research funding into [[Renewable energy|renewables]] since 2001 with just £64k of total funding from fossil fuel companies; and no [[Honorary degree|honorary degrees]] or board positions held by fossil fuel executives.{{cite web|title=City, University of London People & Planet University League 2016 Scorecard|url=https://peopleandplanet.org/university/129364/ul16|publisher=[[People & Planet]]|accessdate=30 July 2017}} ==Notable people== ===Notable alumni=== ====Arts, science and academia==== [[File:Iqbal.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[Muhammad Iqbal]]]] * [[L. Bruce Archer]] – British mechanical engineer and Professor of Design Research at the [[Royal College of Art]] * [[John Brignell]] – former professor of Industrial Instrumentation, science author * [[George Daniels (watchmaker)|George Daniels]] – Horologist, regarded as the greatest watchmaker of modern times and inventor of the [[coaxial escapement]] * [[Jerry Fishenden]] – technologist, former Microsoft National Technology Officer for the UK{{cite web|title=Microsoft UK's national technology officer moves on|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240089572/Microsoft-UKs-national-technology-officer-moves-on|website=Computer Weekly|accessdate=17 December 2016}} * [[Julia Gomelskaya]] – Ukrainian contemporary music composer, professor of Odessa State Music Academy in Ukraine * [[Norman Gowar]] – Professor of Mathematics at the [[Open University]] and Principal of [[Royal Holloway College]], University of London * [[Clare Hammond]] – Concert pianist * [[David Hirsh]] – Academic and sociologist * [[Muhammad Iqbal]] – Muslim poet, philosopher and politician, born in present-day Pakistan, graduated from the Inns of Court School of Law and University of Cambridge * [[John Loder (sound engineer)|John Loder]] – sound engineer, record producer and founder of [[Southern Studios]], as well as a former member of [[EXIT (performance art group)|EXIT]] * [[Sharon Maguire]] – director of ''[[Bridget Jones's Diary (film)|Bridget Jones's Diary]]'' * [[Rhodri Marsden]] – Journalist, musician and blogger; columnist for ''[[The Independent]]'' * [[Robin Milner]] – computer scientist and recipient of the 1991 [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] [[Turing Award]] * [[John Palmer (20th-century composer)|John Palmer]] – instrumental and electroacustic music composer * [[Ziauddin Sardar]] – Academic and scholar of Islamic issues, Commissioner of the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]] * [[Kevin Smith]] – Chartered Engineer; Notable leader in the regeneration of the [[Great Eastern Hotel, London|Great Eastern Hotel]], London ====Government, politics and society==== [[File:Herbert Henry Asquith.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[H. H. Asquith|Herbert Henry Asquith]]]] * [[Clement Attlee]] – [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] from 1945 to 1951 * [[H. H. Asquith|Herbert Henry Asquith]] – [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1908 to 1916 * [[Tony Blair]] – Labour Party Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1997 to 2007, graduated from the [[Inns of Court School of Law]] * [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] – founder of Pakistan, first [[Governor-General of Pakistan]] graduated from the Inns of Court School of Law * [[Roderic Bowen]] – Welsh Liberal Party politician * [[Robert Chote]] - chief of the [[Office for Budget Responsibility]]; former director of [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] * [[Ali Dizaei]] - former police commander * [[Jody Dunn]] – [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] politician, and a barrister specialising in [[family law]] * [[Sir James Dutton]] – Royal Marine general and former deputy commander of the [[International Security Assistance Force]] * [[Chloë Fox]] – Australian politician, former [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] MP for the South Australian [[electoral district of Bright]] * [[Syed Sharifuddin Pirzada]] – Noted Pakistani lawyer & Politician. Also served as 5th secretary general of [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]]. * [[Mahatma Gandhi]] - Leader of the [[Indian Independence Movement]], graduated 1891 from City Law School (Inns of Court School of Law) * [[James Hart (police commissioner)|James Hart]] – Commissioner of the [[City of London Police]] * [[David Heath (politician)|David Heath]] – Politician and Liberal Democrat Member of Parliament for [[Somerton and Frome (UK Parliament constituency)|Somerton and Frome]] * [[Syed Kamall]] – [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] politician and [[Member of the European Parliament]] for the [[London (European Parliament constituency)|London European Parliament constituency]] * [[David Lammy]] – Labour MP for Tottenham * [[Liu Mingkang]] – Chinese Politician and Businessman, current Chairman of the [[China Banking Regulatory Commission]], former Vice-Governor of the [[China Development Bank]] * [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] – First [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] of the Republic of India * [[Houda Nonoo]] – Bahraini Ambassador to the United States * [[Patrick O'Flynn]] – [[UK Independence Party]] MEP * [[Stav Shaffir]] – Youngest member of the Israeli [[Knesset]], leader of the [[social justice]] movement * [[Aris Spiliotopoulos]] – Minister of Greek Tourism * [[Margaret Thatcher]] – Conservative Party Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990, graduated from the [[Inns of Court School of Law]] * [[Ivy Williams]] – First woman to be called to the [[English bar]] ====Business and finance==== [[File:Muhtar A. Kent.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[Muhtar Kent]]]] * [[Winston Set Aung]] - Politician, Economist and Management Consultant, incumbent Deputy Governor of the [[Central Bank of Myanmar]] * [[Brendan Barber]] – General Secretary of the [[Trades Union Congress]]{{cite web |url=http://www.tuc.org.uk/the_tuc/about_bbarber.cfm |title=Biographical details: Brendan Barber |publisher=Trades Union Congress |accessdate=24 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725084803/http://www.tuc.org.uk/the_tuc/about_bbarber.cfm |archivedate=25 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} *[[Jonathan Breeze]] – Founder and CEO of [[Jet Republic]], private jet airline company in Europe{{cite web|url = http://www.ptceducation.com/PROFILES/city.html|title = City University- Institution Profiles|publisher = PTC|accessdate = 2012-11-30|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130131200025/http://www.ptceducation.com/PROFILES/city.html|archivedate = 31 January 2013|df = dmy-all}} * [[William Castell]] – former Chairman of the [[Wellcome Trust]] and a Director of [[General Electric]] and [[BP]], former CEO of [[Amersham plc]] * [[Peter Cullum]] – British entrepreneur * [[James J. Greco]] – former CEO and President of [[Sbarro]] * [[Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou]] – Founder of [[easyGroup]] * [[Robert P. Kelly|Bob Kelly]] – former CEO of [[Bank of New York Mellon]] and CFO of [[Mellon Financial Corporation]] and [[Wachovia Corporation]] * [[Muhtar Kent]] – current Chairman and former CEO [[The Coca-Cola Company]] * [[William Lewis (journalist)|William Lewis]] – CEO [[Dow Jones]] Publisher, ''The Wall Street Journal''{{cite web|url=http://www.dowjones.com/team/william-lewis-3/|title=Dow Jones|website=DowJones.com|access-date=20 November 2017}} * [[Ian Livingstone (property developer)|Ian Livingstone]] – Chairman and co-owner, [[London & Regional Properties]]{{cite web|title=Ian Livingstone|url=http://www.berlinconference.com/index.php/speaker_profile/ian_livingstone|publisher=Questex Hospitality+Travel Group|accessdate=8 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208150928/http://www.berlinconference.com/index.php/speaker_profile/ian_livingstone|archivedate=8 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} * [[Liu Mingkang]] - former Chairman of the [[China Banking Regulatory Commission]]{{cite web|title=Professor Liu|url=http://www.igef.cuhk.edu.hk/index.php/en/people/professor-liu-mingkang/biography}} * [[Dick Olver]] – former Chairman of [[BAE Systems]], member of the Board of Directors at [[Reuters]] * [[Syed Ali Raza]] – former President and Chairman of the [[National Bank of Pakistan]] * [[Martin Wheatley]] - former CEO of the [[Financial Conduct Authority]] * [[Brian Wynter]] – Governor of the Bank of Jamaica * [[Durmuş Yılmaz]] – Governor of the Central Bank of Turkey ====Media and entertainment==== [[File:Sophie raworth.JPG|upright|thumb|right|[[Sophie Raworth]]]] * [[Samira Ahmed]] - [[Channel 4 News]] presenter, [[BBC News]] presenter, writer and journalist * [[Joanna Blythman]] – Non-fiction writer, Britain's leading investigative food journalist * [[Emily Buchanan]] – BBC World Affairs correspondent * [[Ellie Crisell]] – [[BBC]] Presenter * [[Imogen Edwards-Jones]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} – Novelist * [[Gamal Fahnbulleh]] – [[Sky News]] Presenter and journalist * [[Michael Fish]] – [[BBC Weather|BBC]] weatherman * [[Adam Fleming (journalist)|Adam Fleming]] – [[CBBC]] Reporter * [[Lourdes Garcia-Navarro]] – Journalist, [[Jerusalem]] foreign correspondent for [[National Public Radio]] (NPR) * [[Alex Graham (producer)|Alex Graham]] – Chairman of PACT and the [[Scott Trust Limited|Scott Trust]] * [[Michael Grothaus]] – Novelist and journalist; author of ''Epiphany Jones'' * [[Gillian Joseph]] – Sky News Presenter * [[Kirsty Lang]] – BBC Presenter and journalist * [[Ellie Levenson]] – Freelance Journalist and Author * [[William Lewis (journalist)|William Lewis]] – Journalist and editor of the [[Daily Telegraph]] * [[Donal MacIntyre]] – Investigative journalist * [[Sharon Maguire]] – Writer and Director, directed ''[[Bridget Jones's Diary (film)|Bridget Jones's Diary]]'' * [[Rhodri Marsden]] – Journalist, musician and blogger; columnist for ''[[The Independent]]'' * [[Sharon Mascall]] – Journalist, broadcaster and writer; lecturer at the [[University of South Australia]] * [[Lucrezia Millarini]] - Freelance Journalist and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] News Reader * [[Dermot Murnaghan]] – Presenter on Sky News * [[Tiff Needell]] – [[Formula One|Grand Prix]] driver, Presenter of ''[[Fifth Gear]]'' on [[Five (channel)|Five]] * [[Nishat Monsur]] - British singer, musician and writer. * [[Linda Papadopoulos]] – Psychologist, appearing occasionally on TV * [[Catherine Pepinster]] – journalist, religion writer * [[Raj Persaud]] – British consultant psychiatrist, broadcaster, and author on psychiatry * [[Richard Preston]] – Novelist * [[Gavin Ramjaun]] – Television presenter and journalist * [[Sophie Raworth]] – Newsreader, presenter on BBC One O'Clock News * [[Apsara Reddy]] — journalist * [[Joel Rubin]] – World-renowned ''klezmer'' [[clarinet]]ist * [[Ian Saville]] – British magician * [[Barbara Serra]] –presenter for [[Al Jazeera]] from London * [[Sarah Walker (music broadcaster)|Sarah Walker]] – BBC Radio 3 presenter * [[Mark Worthington (journalist)|Mark Worthington]] – BBC Correspondent *[[Maryam Nemazee]] –presenter for [[Al Jazeera]] from London ===Notable faculty and staff=== [[File:David Willetts.jpg|upright|thumb|right|[[David Willets]]]] * [[Rosemary Crompton]] - Professor of Sociology * [[Roy Greenslade]] – Journalist * [[Steven Haberman]] – Professor of [[Actuarial Science]] at City, University of London * [[Rosemary Hollis]] – Professor of [[International Politics]] at City, University of London * [[Jamal Nazrul Islam]] – Physicist, Mathematician, Cosmologist, Astronomer * [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] – Journalist * [[Penny Marshall (UK journalist)|Penny Marshall]] – Journalist * [[David Marks (psychologist)|David Marks]] – Psychologist * [[Stewart Purvis]] – Broadcaster * [[Denis Smalley]] – Composer * [[Bill Thompson (technology writer)|Bill Thompson]] – Journalist * [[David Willets]] – [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] Member of Parliament for [[Havant (constituency)|Havant]]; Shadow [[Secretary of State for Education and Skills]] ===Vice-Chancellors=== * 1966–1974: Sir [[James Sharp Tait]] * 1974–1978: Sir [[Edward Parkes|Edward W. Parkes]] * 1978–1998: [[Raoul Franklin]] * 1998–2007: [[David William Rhind]] * 2007–2009: [[Malcolm Gillies]] * 2009–2010: [[Julius Weinberg]] (acting) * 2010–present: Sir [[Paul Curran (geographer)|Paul Curran]] ==In popular culture== City University's Bastwick Street Halls of Residence in [[Islington]] was the first home of the [[MasterChef (UK TV series)|MasterChef kitchen]] following its 2005 revival.{{cite web|url=http://www.ukgameshows.com/ukgs/Masterchef_Goes_Large|title=MasterChef Studio}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/entertainment/news/a43018/things-you-didnt-know-about-masterchef/|title=MasterChef Studio}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|City University}} * [http://www.city.ac.uk/ City, University of London] * [http://www.culsu.co.uk/ City, University of London, Students Union] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100914105055/http://www.shl.lon.ac.uk/specialcollections/archives/studentrecords.shtml Lists of Northampton Polytechnic Institute students] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130510143909/http://www.senatehouselibrary.ac.uk/our-collections/historic-collections/archives-manuscripts/university-of-london-military-service-1914-1945/ List of Northampton Polytechnic Institute military personnel, 1914–1918] {{City University London|state=expanded}} {{Navboxes|list1= {{University of London}} {{UCL Partners}} {{Universities and colleges in London}} {{Universities in the United Kingdom}} {{1908 Summer Olympics venues}} {{Olympic venues boxing}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} [[Category:City, University of London| ]] [[Category:Optometry schools]] [[Category:Schools of informatics]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in London]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1894]] [[Category:1894 establishments in England]] [[Category:Venues of the 1908 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic boxing venues]]

revision.comment: /* In Orthodontic treatments */ adjusted cochrane content.
revision.text:
{{Infobox interventions | Name = Dental bonding |The first US dentist to promote adhesion dentistry is Ray Bertolotti. He started lecturing "Total etch, total bond total success in 1986. As a friend and colleague of Takeo Fusiyama, Ray introduced the US dental community to dentin bonding. Ray frequently lectures around the world. If you have not heard him you should attend one of his seminars. Thanks Ray! Image = | Caption = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | MeshID = D001840 | OPS301 = | OtherCodes = | HCPCSlevel2 = }} '''Adhesive dentistry''' is a branch of dentistry which deals with adhesion or bonding to the natural substance of teeth, [[tooth enamel|enamel]] and [[dentin]]. It studies the nature and strength of adhesion to dental hard tissues, properties of adhesive materials, causes and mechanisms of failure of the bonds, clinical techniques for bonding and newer applications for bonding such as bonding to the soft tissue.<ref>[http://jad.quintessenz.de/ The Journal of Adhesive Dentistry: Online Introduction]</ref> There's also direct composite bonding which uses tooth-colored [[dental composite|direct dental composites]] to repair various tooth damages such as cracks or gaps.
Dental bonding is a dental procedure in which a dentist applies a tooth-colored [[resin]] material (a durable [[plastic]] material) and cures it with visible, blue light. This ultimately "bonds" the material to the tooth and improves the overall appearance of teeth.<ref>[http://authoritydentalblog.com/best-denture-adhesive/ Denture Adhesive]</ref> Tooth bonding techniques have various clinical applications including operative dentistry and preventive dentistry as well as [[cosmetic dentistry|cosmetic]] and [[pediatric dentistry]], [[prosthodontics]], and [[orthodontics]].
==History== Adhesive dentistry began in 1955 with a paper by Dr. Michael Buonocore on the benefits of acid etching.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cdeworld.com/courses/4508-the-history-of-adhesive-bonding |title=The History of Adhesive Bonding |publisher=CDEWorld}}</ref> Technologies have changed multiple times since then, with generally recognized generations established in the literature.<ref>{{Citation |first=Ara |last= Nazarian |title=The Progression of Dental Adhesives |url=http://www.aranazariandds.com/pdf/dental_adhesives.pdf}}</ref> Dental bonding agents have evolved from no-etch to total-etch (4th- and 5th-generation) to self-etch (6th- and 7th-generation) systems.<ref>De Munck J, Van Landuyt KL, Peumans M, Poitevin A, Lambrechts P, Braem M, Van Meerbeek B. A critical review of the durability of adhesion to tooth tissue: methods and results. J Dent Res 2005;84:118-132.</ref> The evolution of products improved convenience and reduced sensitivity to operator errors. However, the best bonding and longevity was achieved with 4th generation agents (having separate etch, prime, and bond steps).<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Ernest CP, Holzmeier M, Willershausen B|title=In vitro shear bond strength of self-etching adhesives in comparison to 4th and 5th generation adhesives.|journal=J Adhes Dent.|date=Winter 2004|volume=6|issue=4|pages=293–9|pmid=15779314}}</ref> [[File:Dental bonding agents.jpg|thumb|All in one self-etch adhesive and a single component universal adhesive by Kerr, both used in the adhesion of direct and indirect dental restorations ]] [[Irwin Smigel]] founder and current president of the [[American Society for Dental Aesthetics]] and diplomat of the American Board of Aesthetic Dentistry, was one of the first to broaden the usage of bonding by using it to close gaps between teeth, lengthen teeth as well as to re-contour the entire mouth rather than using crowns. Having done more extensive work on the process than any other dentist, Dr. Smigel lectures world-wide on aesthetic dentistry. In 1979 he published a guide to aesthetic dentistry entitled “Dental Health/Dental Beauty.”<ref>{{cite book |last=Smigel |first=Irwin |title=Dental Health/Dental Beauty |year=1979 |publisher=M. Evans |isbn=978-0-87131-284-6}}</ref>
In 2012, new dental universal adhesives are commercialized. The universal adhesives bond to all dental substrates, which include enamel, dentin, metal, porcelain, ceramic and zirconia, with a single application. The term “universal” adhesive is not new. In fact, many early bonding agents were named or described as “universal” adhesives, such as XP Bond-Universal Total-etch Adhesive (Dentsply), One-Step-Universal Dental Adhesive (Bisco). However, there is still not a definition of dental “universal adhesive”. It is highly confusing what the term “universal” means. In 2012, the term “universal adhesive” has several definitions which may include:<ref>Christensen G. New universal adhesives (part I): are they better? Clinicians Report 2012;5(3): 1-4.</ref> a)Can be used in total-etch, self-etch, and selective etch techniques; b)Can be used with light-cure, self-cure, and dual-cure materials (without the separate activators); c)Can be used for both direct and indirect substrates; d)Can bond to all dental substrates, such as dentin, enamel, metal, ceramic, porcelain, and zirconia.
== In Orthodontic treatments == Bonding of orthodontic brackets to teeth is crucial to enable effective treatment with fixed appliances. There is no clear evidence on which to make a clinical decision of the type of orthodontic adhesive to use.<ref>{{Citation|last=Mandall|first=Nicky A.|title=Adhesives for fixed orthodontic brackets|date=2018-04-09|url=http://cochranelibrary-wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD002282.pub2/full|work=The Cochrane Library|publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Ltd|language=en|doi=10.1002/14651858.cd002282.pub2|access-date=2018-06-28|last2=Hickman|first2=Joy|last3=Macfarlane|first3=Tatiana V.|last4=Mattick|first4=Rye CR|last5=Millett|first5=Declan T.|last6=Worthington|first6=Helen V.}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Fixed prosthodontics]] *[[Cosmetic dentistry]]

{{Infobox disease| Name = Ectopic testis | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|Q|53|0}} | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | eMedicine_mult = | MeshID = | }} A '''ectopic testis''' is a [[testicle]] that, although not an [[undescended testicle]], has taken a non-standard path through the body and ended up in an unusual location.
The positions of the ectopic testis may be: in the lower part of the abdomen, front of thigh, femoral canal, skin of penis or behind the scrotum. The testis is usually developed, and accompanied by an indirect inguinal hernia. It may be divorced from the epididymis which may lie in the scrotum.<ref>{{cite book | first1 = Roger | last1 = Stevenson | first2 = Judith | last2 = Hall | title = Human malformations and related anomalies | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-19-516568-3 | page= 1272}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gpnotebook.co.uk/simplepage.cfm?ID=422903814|title=Ectopic testis|publisher=GP Notebook|accessdate=2011-12-15}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
